feedback.html: Correct! 3 * (2 * 5) means we have to multiply 2 * 5 first to get 10. Then, we multiply 10 * 3 to get 30. We still get the same answer because it doesn't matter which numbers you multiply first.
No, that's not right. 3 * (2 * 5) means you multiply 2 * 5 first, and then multiply its product by 3. Try again!

content.html:
“Correct!” said Omar. “Notice that there were three ways to solve the last question! In 3 * 7 * 4, You could have multiplied 3 * 7 first, multiplied 7 * 4 first, or multiplied 3 * 4 first!"

“Wow!” said Aria and her friends. “You can group the numbers in any order!”

“Right! That’s why we can write this expression in three ways:"

  • (3 * 7) * 4
  • (7 * 4) * 3
  • (4 * 3) * 7

“What are the parentheses for?” wondered Aria aloud.

“In math, whatever is inside the parentheses has to be done first,” explained Omar. “So, when we write something like (1 * 2) * 3, we specifically mean that you have to multiply 1 * 2 first, and then multiply by 3.”

"I want to see if that's true!" said Aria's friend Nina. "(3 * 2) * 5 means we multiply 3 * 2 first to get 6. Then, we multiply 6 * 5 to get 30. (3 * 2) * 5 = 30! What is 3 * (2 * 5)?"

"Okay!" said Omar. "Are you ready? We're going to multiply 25 * 21 using the carry method, one factor at a time!"

"Ready!" said Aria.

"First of all, understand that multiplying by 21 is the same as multiplying by 20, multiplying by 1, and adding the results together. So, 25 * 21 = 25 * (20 + 1) = (25 * 20) + (25 * 1)."

"Will we use this information with the carry method?" asked Aria.

"Yes!" said Omar. "First, we will multiply 25 by the 1 in 21. Then, we will multiply 25 by the 20 in 21. Finally, we will add up the two products to get our final answer."

Welcome back! It's the weekend, and Aria and Omar are sitting in Aria's schoolyard with some of Aria's friends. In the last chapter, Aria made plans for a school garden she wanted to start. Today, she and her friends will plant it with Omar's help!

In this lesson, we will finish our Multiplication journey by learning how to multiply multi-digit numbers together. You should be able to do the following before going on:

  • How to quickly recall the result of multiplying any two single-digit numbers (from 0 to 9)

  • How to multiply numbers in cases where one factor ends with “0"s

  • How to multiply a multi-digit number with a single-digit number

You should also get some paper and a pen or pencil to write with, and find a quiet place to work. Be sure to take your time and go through the story at your own pace. Understanding is more important than speed!

Once you’re ready, click Continue to get started!

Each day at school, Aria and her friends studied hard and played in the garden every afternoon.

One day, when they were playing hide-and-seek in the garden, Aria's friend Matthew pointed at a soil bed and said, "Look!"

Aria squinted and then smiled. There were tiny green plants in the soil bed. "Our pumpkin and corn plants have started to grow!"

feedback.html: Correct! The Associative Property of Multiplication says that if more than two factors are being multiplied together, the order in which they are grouped does not matter.

No, that's not correct. The distributive property of multiplication states that when a number is multiplied by the sum of two numbers, the first number can be distributed to both of those numbers, and all the products can be added together. Try again!

content.html:
"Correct!" said Omar. "Now, which rule makes this statement true?"

23 * (5 * 34) = (23 * 5) * 34

Read this card carefully! It is very important to understand.

"Wow!" said Omar. "That was a lot to learn. To make sure you understood it, Aria, can you explain to me what I just did to solve 25 * 21 using the carry method?"

"Sure," said Aria. She paused to think before answering.

"First," continued Aria. "Because 25 * 21 is the same thing as (20 + 5) * (20 + 1), we multiply the ones places together first. 5 * 1 = 5. Because there's nothing to carry to the tens place, I'm going to write a 0 above it."

"Then, we multiply the tens place of 25 by the ones place of 21. 2 * 1 = 2. So, we write a 2 in the tens place."

"Next, we move on to the second row and write the ''0' needed in its ones place before we multiply the ones place of 25 by the tens place of 21."

"5 * 2 = 10. Carry the 1, and write another 0 in the tens place of the answer's second row."

"Finally, multiply the tens places together. 2 * 2 = 4. We carried a 1, so add it to 4 to get 4 + 1 = 5. So, we write a 5 in the hundreds place of the answer's second row."

"We have a 25 in the answer's first row, and a 500 in the second row. Adding 25 + 500 gives us a final answer of 525."

"Perfect!" said Omar. "I'm really proud of you for working so hard to understand! Now, let's practice."

"Great work!” said Omar as the kids worked on planting their pumpkins. Aria was excited! In three months, the school garden would be filled with big, bright, orange pumpkins!"

"What should we plant next?" asked Aria.

"Let's plant corn!" exclaimed Miguel.

feedback.html: Correct!
No, that's not correct. Remember to multiply two factors first, and then multiply their product by the third factor. Try again!

content.html:
“I like it when there are only two factors," said Aria. "So, in 93 * 4 * 32, I will multiply two of the numbers first, like 93 * 4,” said Aria. "Then, I will take the product of 93 * 4 and multiply it by 32."

“Exactly!” said Omar, happy that Aria was learning. “When you have a big multiplication expression where you have to multiply three or more factors, you should always multiply two numbers first and then multiply their product by the third number.”

“So, in this case, 93 * 4 * 32 is…”

feedback.html: Correct!
No, that's not right. Go back to the previous examples and reread Omar's explanations if you need to. Then, try again!

content.html:
“Well done, Aria!” said Omar. “The next problem I’m about to show you has a three-digit factor. But, don’t worry, it still uses the same method!” said Omar.

 “Okay," said Aria. “But, why are there two zeros in the ones and tens places of the third row?” she asked.

"Because we solve the number in the third row by multiplying a 2 in the hundreds place by 15," said Omar, "we add zeros to the ones and tens places of the third row to show that there’s nothing there!”

“Okay,” Aria said again, “there are no boxes above the problem to carry numbers. Does this mean I still have to carry them?”

“Yes.” said Omar. "I haven't written boxes for the carried numbers because you'll be carrying lots of them! You still need to carry them when you’re doing your work on paper! This is why you should do your work on paper first and then fill in the boxes!” Follow Omar's advice and fill in the boxes on paper, then type your final answer below.

Fill in the boxes on paper, and type your final answer below.

For 3 months, Aria and her friends played in the garden after school and watched their plants grow until, one day, the garden was filled with tall corn plants and gigantic orange pumpkins!

Aria and her friends marveled at the results of all their hard work. After weeks and weeks of learning Multiplication, their work had finally paid off with a spectacular garden!

As they stood there admiring their garden, Omar arrived. He smiled at Aria and her friends. What an achievement! Omar had successfully taught Aria multiplication, and now, she knew how to use it to solve problems in the real world!

Congratulations! In this exploration, you and Aria learned about:

  • Evaluating multi-digit multiplication expressions

  • The Associative Property of Multiplication

  • Using the Associative Property to evaluate multi-factor multiplication expressions

feedback.html: Correct!
No, that's not right. The number of desks in Aria's school is the product to 25 * 21. Try again!

hint_content.html: 25 * 21 is the problem which Aria and Omar worked through on this card. The answer is in yellow, in the last picture.

content.html:
“Next, to start the second row of the answer, we multiply 25 * 2!"

“But, first, remember this because it is very important!" said Omar. "Because the 2 in '21' that we are multiplying to find the second row of the answer is in the tens place, we need to add a zero in the ones place of the second row in the answer to show that there are no 1s there,” finished Omar.

"First, we need to multiply the ones place of 25 by 2, so, 5 * 2 = 10.”

After thinking for a moment, Aria said, “So, I'm guessing, first you write a 0 in the ones place of the second line. Then, you solve 5 * 2 = 10, so you write another 0 in the second row and carry the 1!”

“Exactly!” said Omar. "Now, all you need to do is multiply the tens place of 25 by 2. So, 2 * 2 = 4. Since you carried a 1 in the last step, you add it to 4, to get 5.”

“Sweet!” said Aria. “But, now what?”

“Now, it’s simple!” said Omar. “Just take the numbers from your rows and add them up to get the final answer! In this case, the answer represents the number of desks in your entire school.”

“According to our multiplication, how many total desks are there in Aria’s school?”

feedback.html: Correct!
No, that's not correct. Remember to draw a "carrying diagram" for 242 * 101. Look at the previous examples if you need help, and try again!

content.html: "Sure!" said Aria as she brought out some corn seeds. "We have enough seeds to plant 115 corn plants. If each corn plant grows two ears of corn, how many total ears of corn will grow? Remember, to make it easier for you to use the carry method, you should always write the bigger number at the top, and the smaller number at the bottom!"

feedback.html: Well done!
No, that's not correct. Look at the previous examples for clues, and try again!

content.html: “Wonderful work!” said Omar. “Before we solve this one, what number goes in the boxes labeled A, B, and C?”

feedback.html: Correct!
No, that's not correct. You are correct that 525 is the number of desks :) But first, write the multiplication expression to find the number of desks. Try again!
No, that's not right. If you forgot how to write a multiplication expression, go back and read [refresher lesson] (LINK: Subtopic Cards: Multiplication Expression given Situation)

content.html:
We left Aria as she was learning how to multiply numbers with multi-digit factors. This is an important topic, so look back at the last lesson if you want to refresh your memory.

At school, Aria's classroom is very big. “Every classroom has 25 desks!” she exclaimed to Omar.

“And there are 21 classrooms in the school!" added Aria's friend Matthew. "I wonder how many kids there are.”

Omar smiled. “If there are 21 classrooms in the school and 25 desks, write a multiplication expression that we can use to find the total number of desks in the school!”

“Perfect!” said Omar. “25 * 21 is the expression you can use to calculate the total number of kids in your school. Now…do you remember the carrying method we learnt?”

“Yeah!” said Aria. "But, how do you solve such a big expression? Do I have to memorize the 25 times table? That would be hard!"

"Don't worry!" said Omar. "I'm going to teach you how to use the carry method to solve multiplication expressions where there is more than one multi-digit factor. Let’s see how!”

“Great! Now, let's make this a little easier for you. Imagine that we are only multiplying 25 by the rightmost digit of 21, which is 1, and the rest of the number 21 (the 2 part) isn't there! So, we would start off by multiplying using the same method we just learnt, where there was only 1 digit to multiply. Isn't that easy?" asked Omar.

"Yes!" said Aria. "If we pretend that the 2 isn't there, then this is just long multiplication with 1 digit, like we did last time! But how can we just remove the 2? Won't our answer be wrong?" asked Aria.

"Well," said Omar, "we're not exactly removing the 2! We're just imagining that it isn't there for now, to make our job easier! We're going to come back to the 2 later, before getting our final answer. Don't worry!" answered Omar.

"So, pretend the 2 in 21 isn't there. Now, just like we did last lesson, the first step in 25 * 1 is multiplying the ones place of 25, which is 5, by 1. So, 5 * 1 = 5." said Omar. 

“Then, because we don’t have anything to carry, we move on to multiply the tens place in 25, which is 2, by 1. So, 2 * 1 = 2!” said Aria. 

“Yep!” said Omar. “The first step is the exact same as what we learned last lesson! Now that we’re done multiplying 25 by 1, which is in the ones place of 21, we need to start a second row in the answer, for multiplying 25 by the tens place of 21, which is 2!”

feedback.html: Correct! Well done!
No, that's not correct. 525 is the answer to 25 * 21! but this question is asking you to solve 16 * 24. Try again!
No, that's not right. Go back to Omar's explanation for multiplying 25 * 21 (two multi-digit factors) if you are confused. Then, use the hints if you need to, and try again!

hint_content.html:
In 16 * 24, we must first calculate the top row of the answer. 

To do this, we do the following:

  1. Multiply the ones place of 16 by the ones place of 24. 
  • 6 * 4 = 24
  • In 24, put the "4" in the ones place of the answer's first row.
  • In 24, carry the "2" above the tens place of 16.

The next step is to multiply the tens place of 16 by the ones place of 24.

The next step is to multiply the tens place of 16 by the ones place of 24.

1 * 4 = 4. Then, we add the 2 we carried above the tens place to 4. The first row of the answer is complete. Now, erase the "2" you carried before moving on to evaluating the second row of the answer.

Now that we are done calculating the first row of the answer, it is time to caluclate the second row of the answer, and the tens place of 24.

The next thing we need to calculate is the ones place of 16 multiplied by the tens place of 24. In other words, 6 * 2 = 12.

In 12, we put the "2" left of the "0" in the answer's second row. We carry the "1" above the "1" in 16.

Next, we multiply the tens place of 16 by the tens place of 24. In other words, 1 * 2 = 2.

Then, we add the "1" we carried to the 2 to get 1 + 2 = 3. The last box in the answer's second row is a "3".
Finally, we add the answer's first row and its second row to get the answer. In this case, evaluate 64 + 320 to get the final answer, and type it in when you are done!

content.html:
“Wonderful job,” praised Omar. “That was a tricky concept! Make sure to go back to it if you need to.”

“Great!” continued Omar. “Now that you see how to multiply two double-digit factors together, I want you to do a couple problems for practice!”

   


“Copy this diagram on your paper and solve it just like we did for 25 * 21. As you fill in the boxes, remember that in a double-digit multiplication problem, there is always a zero in the ones place of the answer's second row,” said Omar. “Go back to the last card if you forgot why!”

"What if I get stuck?" asked Aria. "This is my first time doing this on my own!"

"Don't worry!" said Omar. "If you need more help, look at the hints. They are here to help you!"

“After you’re done, enter your final answer below!”

feedback.html: Correct!
No, that's not correct. If you need help understanding how to multiply two multi-digit numbers, go back to Omar's explanation of 25 * 21. Then, use a hint if you need to, and try again!

hint_content.html: The multiplication expression for this problem is 97 * 15 because 15 seeds must be planted to grow 1 pumpkin, and Aria and her friends want 97 pumpkins.
Write 97 * 15 in carrying form on your paper and solve it.

This is what 97 * 15 looks like in carrying form. Fill in the boxes and submit your final answer.

Note that the "carrying box" above the 9 might need to be erased after the first row of the answer has been filled, so another number can be carried when calculating the second row of the answer.

content.html:
“Marvelous!” Omar exclaimed. “Now, that you've learned how to multiply two double-digit numbers, let's get started on the school garden!"

Aria and her friends want to grow pumpkins. There are 97 soil beds to grow them! If each soil bed can grow 15 pumpkins, how many pumpkin seeds must they plant?

Work this one out in a notebook or on a piece of paper, using the same method you learned in the last few problems!

feedback.html: Correct!

No, that's not right. If you want to refresh your memory on how to multiply two multi-digit numbers, go back to the example with 25 * 21 and look at Omar's explanation again. Use a hint if you need to, and try again!

hint_content.html: The second row of the answer is the product of 57 and the "1" in 17. Because the "1" in 17 is in the tens place, it is the same thing as multiplying 57 * 10. There is always a "0" in the ones place of the answer's second row.
This is 57 * 15 written using the "carry method." Copy this diagram on your paper, fill in the boxes, and submit your final answer!

content.html: “You’re doing great!” said Omar. “Now, solve 57 * 15 using the 'carrying method' diagram we used in the last two problems! Draw the diagram on to your paper, solve the question, and submit your final answer!”

feedback.html: Good job!
No, that's not correct. Try again!

content.html:
“Good start!” said Omar. “Now, let’s think about this another way. Let's say we need to count the number of cubes in this big cuboid. Can you think of a way to do this? 

"We can cut the rectangle into slices, and count the number of cubes in each slice!" said Aria.

"Good idea!" said Omar. "Let's do that. Since the cuboid has a thickness of 4 cubes, we would get 4 slices!"

"Now, what multiplication expression would we use to calculate the number of cubes in 1 slice?" asked Omar.

"3 * 7, because each slice is 3 cubes wide and 7 cubes long!" said Aria.

"Good! Now, which multiplication expression can we use to find the number of cubes in 4 slices?" asked Omar.

feedback.html: Correct!
No, that's not correct. First, write a multiplication expression to find the total number of grapes, and solve. Try again!

content.html: You got it! There are 2,000 grape bunches on the fruit farm. If there are 79 grapes in each grape bunch, how many grapes are there on the farm in total?

feedback.html: Correct!
No, that's not correct. First, write a multiplication expression to find the total blueberries, and write down your work using the "carry method" on paper. Try again!

content.html:
Well done! Aria's friend Miguel also points out that there are 235 blueberry bushes on the farm.

If each blueberry bush has nine blueberries, how many total blueberries are on the fruit farm?

feedback.html: Correct!
No, that's not correct. First, write a multiplication expression to find the total number of grape bunches, and solve. Try again!

content.html:
Before we begin our latest exploration of multiplication with Aria, let’s recap what we learned in the last few lessons!

Last week, Aria's friend Nina took everyone to visit her aunt's fruit farm. There were 400 grapevines on the farm! If each grapevine grows five grape bunches, how many total grape bunches are in the farm?

“Awesome job!” exclaimed Omar as Aria and her friends started planting their corn seeds.

“We just have one more topic left before you have learned all of Multiplication! So far, we have been multiplying two numbers together. But, now I need to figure out something a little trickier. I have four beds of soil. Each bed of soil can hold 93 corn seeds, and each corn seed needs 32 ml of water. If I completely fill all my beds with seeds, how much water will I need for all of them?" Omar asked.

"There's three factors here!” said Aria. "First, I would have to multiply 93 * 4 to get the total number of seeds, then I would have to multiply that by 32 to get the total amount of water."

“So, how about an expression like 93 * 4 * 32?” Miguel suggested.

“Yep!” replied Omar. "That's great! Let's solve it now."

feedback.html: Correct!
No, that's not right. The Associative Property of Multiplication is only used when two or more factors are grouped together using parentheses. Try again!

content.html:
“That’s cool!” said Aria. "So, in a three-factor multiplication problem, it doesn't matter which two numbers you multiply first! You will still get the same answer."

“Yes!” said Omar. “For multiplication expressions where you have multiple factors, the order in which you multiply the numbers doesn't matter. This rule actually has a name: the Associative Property of Multiplication.”

“Wait…how is this different from the Commutative Property of Multiplication?" asked Aria.

“Good question!" said Omar.  The Commutative Property means that the order of factors  doesn't change the product, but the Associative Property means that if there are lots of factors in a multiplication expression, you can group certain factors together to create an order for the multiplication, and it doesn't matter how you group them! The answer will be the same."

Which rule makes this statement true: 23 * 5 * 34 = 25 * 34 * 5?

exploration.title: Multi-Digit Multiplication - Part 2
exploration.objective: In this last part of our journey, you will finish learning multi-digit, multi-factor multiplication.
